results.title: Bjorn Wiinblad
results.brief_description: Portrait of the Danish artist and designer. Records Wiinblad’s many talents, including working on ceramics, porcelain, glass vases, wallpapers, textiles, stage sets and costumes, and illustrations for children’s books.

results.title: Bizarre cults
results.creator_credit: Ashley Sidaway, Ellis Elias, John Thompson and 21st Century Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Narrated by Sir David Frost, this program gives a brief overview of some of the major cults from around the world and includes information about what they believe and how they were founded. Cults covered include: Charles Manson’s family; Branch Davidians; Aum Shrinriko, Moonies; the Order of the Solar Temple; Children of God; Hare Krishnas; Druidism; Flagellants; the Spacepeople of Damanhur; the Church of Scientology; Evangelism; Jehovah’s Witness; Voodooism. Personalities covered include: Charles Manson; David Koresh; Shoko Asohara; L. Ron Hubbard; Tammy and Jim Baker.

results.title: Bits and bytes. Parts 1-12
results.creator_credit: David Stansfield, Denise Boiteau, Stuart Beecroft, Time-Life Video and TV Ontario
results.brief_description: Part 1. ‘Getting started’. Part 2. “Ready made programs’. Part 3. ‘How programs work’. Part 4. ‘Storing information’. Part 5. ‘Communication between computers’. Part 6.’Computer languages’. Part 7. ‘Computer assisted instruction’. Part 8. ‘Learning objectives’. Part 9. ‘Computer Graphics’. Part 10 ‘Computer music’. Part 11. ‘Computers at work’. Part 12 ‘What next’. Based on the Apple II series computer, and IBM, there are sound basic explanations about basic computer functions and programs.

results.title: Birth of the Bomb (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is the background story of the making of the first atomic bomb. The period covered is from 1938 to the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. German efforts to create an atomic bomb are described. the intensive research into the development of the bomb in the US is dealt with extensively. Includes archival film and interviews with some of those involved.

results.title: Birth control - How?
results.creator_credit: Frank Slinglarn, Stuart Schulberg, Ted Yates and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Discusses “the pill” and other birth control methods, and describes controlled experiment groups in Kentucky and in Puerto Rico. Examines some of the moral dimensions of birth control.

results.title: Birdlovers of New South Wales: the story of the Gould League
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of the foundation and growth of the Gould League of Birdlovers, who study, watch and protect native birds. Photography by Harry Malcolm with majority of bird shots by Norman Chaffer. Commentary by David Low.

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro and William Gilcher
results.brief_description:
Georges Rouquier revisits the characters of his 1938 ‘Biquefarre’ 35 year later. The family whose farm was wired for electricity in the first film are still on the family spread in 1983. The plot revolves around Raoul who decides to sell the farm to take up a job as gardener with the City of Toulouse. Though documentary in technique, the film is well planned and scripted, with its amateur cast convincingly mouthing the lines given them by Rouqier.

Credits: Producer, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher ; director, Georges Rouquier ; writers, Georges Rouquier, Maria Signorini ; photography, Andre Villard ; music, Yves Gilbert
Cast: Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Roch Rouquier, Raymond Rouquier.

results.title: Bing bang boom
results.creator_credit: Joan Henson, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A novel way of discovering music without instruments, in a Grade 7 classroom. Innovator and Toronto composer R. Murray Shafer is teacher for a day. His purpose is to show children that music is more than painfully learned notes and scales. He has the class listen to every sound around them and then harmonize and orchestrate what they hear - their voices, hands, feet - into a rhythmic musical pattern. The result is a hit, and a convincing illustration that children learn best when it’s from the inside out. Awards: American Film Festival; Sydney.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Henson, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Bill Henson: dreams of darkness
results.creator_credit: Philippe Marie Charluet and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: This program centres around the work of Bill Henson and the exhibition of his work at the Venice Biennale in 1996. Through interviews with Henson himself, colleagues, critics and gallery convenors, his unique, dream-like style of work and exhibition practices are presented and discussed in critical detail. The program touches on many issues related to his work and its presentation including interpretations surrounding the borderline soft pornographic elements to his pieces. Diverse opinions about such issues are drawn from the attendants of the Venice Biennale as well as from the range of interviewees already mentioned, including Henson. It is a visually dense and thorough analytical program offering an interesting insight into the work of this critically acclaimed Australian artist.

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher, Midas and Millia Films
results.brief_description: The title of Georges Rouquier’s final film is the name of a small farm in Aveyron, France and the narrative revolves around the changing nature of farming life there. Within this setting a middle-aged farmer decides to sell up and move to Toulouse, a decision that leads to two neighbours competing to buy, with an array of underhanded methods undertaken to secure the deal. The background to these shenanigans is the daily life and routine of farm life, highlighting the escalating mechanisation, automation of practice and procedures and difficulties inherent within the economics of land ownership, expensive machinery and unstable returns. This naturalistic film works as a companion piece to “Farrebique” (1945); in fact it can almost be read as a sequel to Rouquier’s earlier work in which the same family were carefully considering the introduction of electricity. Using a cast of non-professional actors, and engaging a documentary feel, Rouquier successfully evokes the milieu of rural life, presenting it here in a non-idealised manner, an aesthetic contrast to the evocative bucolic mise-en-scene of “Farrebique”. Cast includes Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Marius Benaben and Helene Benaben.
